0.user_question: A bag has a 5% discount. If it is marked $398072, how much will you pay after the discount?

1.subquestion: How much percentage do I save from the initial price due to the 5% discount?

subanswer.text: With a 5% discount off an item priced at $398072, one would save (5/100) * 398072 = $19903.6. This represents the saving percent out of the initial cost. Answer: Savings= $19903.6.

ost_step.1: Subtracting this from the original price yields your payment due; i.e., Payment Due = Initial Cost – Discount Saving => Payment Due =  398072-$19903.6=$378168.4 .Answer : Amount paid =$378168.4.

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. First we need to calculate the amount saved through the discount which is calculated as follows: (Percentage off / 100) × Original Price or $((5/100)*398072)=$(19903.6). Next subtract the savings from the initial cost so Your new balance would be Calculation=(Original Balance−Discount Saved), therefore ($398072 − $19903.6)=($378168.4) This means if someone buys something priced at $$398072 with a percentage discount of 5%, they’d only owe ${$$378168.4}.

Plugging our numbers into the formula results in (5/100) * $398,072; therefore saving us ($5/100)*$398,072=$19,903.60. To find out how much you actually pay following the application of such reduction, subtract the savings received using your original purchase value minus those obtained during the sale period like so:$398,072-$19,903.60=|$378,168.40| Final

0.user_question: A bag has a 5% discount. If it is marked $398072, how much will you pay after the discount?

1.subquestion: To find out what number represents the price reduction due to the discount, calculate the value equivalent to 5%.

subanswer.text: Since percentages represent parts per hundred, finding 5% (which translates to \( \frac{5}{100} \) or \(\frac{1}{20}\) ) would mean dividing the full price (\$398072) by 20: \$398072 / 20 = \$19903.6. This equals the dollar amount reduced from its initial cost because of the discount. The answer is \$19903.6.

subanswer.text: Yes, since our goal here is indeed to determine an item’s final sale price post-discount application, one should deduct the calculated deduction figure (\$19903.6) from the product's entirety prior to any reductions being applied —\( \$398072 - \$19903.6 = \$378168.4\). Thusly, following a period wherein said commodity benefits under such monetary pruning terms, your required payment equates to approximately \$378168.4 .

0.user_question: A bag has a 5% discount. If it is marked $398072, how much will you pay after the discount?

direct_answer.text: To find out the amount paid after applying a 5% discount, we first need to calculate what this percentage amounts to when applied to the original price ($398072). To get 5% of any value (in this case, the cost), multiply the whole quantity/value by .05 [or 5/100]. Thus, our equation becomes 398072*.05 which equals approximately 19903.6. This figure represents the amount saved due to the discount; hence, subtracting it from the initial cost provides us with the actual payment made upon purchase. Therefore, one pays 398072-$19903.6=378168.4 post-discount. The answer is: 378168.4.
